correction_response: This tweet is partially accurate. It's true that the Energy Department is buying back oil at a lower price than it was sold for, which could be seen as a good deal for taxpayers and a way to strengthen energy security (https://www.reuters.com/business/energy/us-begins-buying-back-oil-strategic-reserve-official-2022-12-16/). However, the claim that this action directly reduced gas prices is misleading. The impact of releasing oil from the SPR on gas prices is not immediate and depends on various factors, including production from the U.S. and OPEC and global relations with Russia (https://www.npr.org/2022/04/03/1090498777/how-releasing-federal-oil-reserves-affects-the-price-at-the-pump). Furthermore, the SPR is an insurance policy for the U.S. economy, and its levels are at their lowest since 1984, raising concerns about energy security (https://www.reuters.com/business/energy/us-begins-buying-back-oil-strategic-reserve-official-2022-12-16/).
note_1_text: The Strategic Petroleum Reserve has been drawn down over 200 million barrels over the past year (~1/3 of the previously stored amount).  https://www.eia.gov/dnav/pet/hist/LeafHandler.ashx?n=pet&s=mcsstus1&f=m     The refill being promoted is to pilot the purchase of up to 3 million barrels in January & deliver in February. https://www.spr.doe.gov/posting/PURCHASE/FY23%20Winter%20Oil%20Purchase%203MMB/1-Request%20for%20Proposal/FY23%20Winter%20Oil%20Purchase%203MMB%20Request%20for%20Proposal.pdf
